facts.text: The assessee is a spinning mill manufacturing company on yarn.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, who is the respondent herein, is a spinning mill manufacturing companyton yarn.

facts.text: Assessee assessed to sales tax under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It was assessed to sales tax under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959, hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: For assessment year 1960-61, assessing authority included sale value of foodgrains and groceries sold in fair price shop in taxable turnover.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1960-61 the assessing authority included in the taxable turnover certain amounts representing the sale value of foodgrains and groceries sold in the fair price shop run by the mills

facts.text: Assessing authority included amount realised by sale of articles of food in the canteen run for employees in taxable turnover for 1960-61.

anchor.surface_text: and the amount realised by sale of articles of food in the canteen which was run for its employees.

facts.text: Assessee filed appeal questioning liability to pay tax on foodgrains, groceries and canteen sales.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed an appeal questioning its liability to pay tax on these items The appellate authority dismissed that appeal.

facts.text: Appellate authority dismissed assessee's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate authority dismissed that appeal.

facts.text: Assessee filed further appeal to Sales tax Appellate Tribunal which allowed the appeal and directed deletion of the turnover.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee thereupon filed a further appeal to the Sales tax Appellate Tribunal which allowed the appeal and directed that the turnover in question be deleted.

facts.text: Revenue filed revision to Madras High Court against Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue went up in revision to the High Court of Madras.

facts.text: Madras High Court division bench dismissed Revenue's revision.

anchor.surface_text: A division bench of that companyrt dismissed the revision.

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 validated the levy and collection of certain taxes in the following terms S.9. Notwithstanding anything contained in any judgment, decree or order of any Court, no levy or collection of any tax under the provisions of the principal Act and of rules made thereunder in respect of sales in the course of business,

concepts.interpretation: Validation provision deeming past levies valid regardless of profit motive; does not make substituted definition retrospective nor cure defect of lack of commercial business activity.

concepts.interpretation: Legislature can validate invalid tax by removing grounds of invalidity (e.g., retrospective reenactment curing defect), but cannot merely declare court judgments ineffective; S.9 fails as it does not address lack of 'business' activity.
concepts.unlisted_description: Requires curing defects like lack of jurisdiction or substantive law compliance, not overriding judgments

concepts.interpretation: Retrospective amendments allowed within limits to declare past law, but cannot nullify valid court judgments.

issues.text: Whether the sales of foodgrains, groceries in the fair price shop and articles in the canteen run by the assessee constitute business under the original definition in clause (d) of section 2 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal had found that the fair price shop and the canteen were run exclusively for the benefit of the employees and there was no profit motive in running the same. The High Court referred to the relevant statutory provisions and expressed the view that the primary requisite of business as defined by the Act should be a trade or commerce or adventure in the nature of trade or commerce. Presence or absence of profit was no material but the activity must be of a commercial character in the course of trade or commerce. It was found that the assessee had no been carrying on business in the fair price shop. The High Court looked into the articles of association of the assessee and found no article empowering it to carry on business in fair price shop. The assessee had opened that shop only to provide an amenity to its workmen so that commodities may be made available to them at fair prices. According to the High Court if as a matter of fact, some profit accrued that would be wholly immaterial because the assessee never intended to run the fair price shop as a business having an element of commercial activity. Section 2 of the Act gives the definitions. The definitions of business given in cl.(d), of dealer as given in cl.(g) and of sale as given in cl.(n) are reproduced below (d) business includes any trade, commerce or manufacture or any adventure or concern in the nature of trade, commerce or manufacture whether or no any profit accrues from such trade, commerce, manufacture, adventure or concern. (g) dealer means any person who carries on the business of buying, selling, supplying or distributing goods, directly or otherwise, whether for cash or for deferred payment or for commission, remuneration or other valuable consideration and includes-

issues.text: Whether section 2 of the Madras General Sales Tax Second Amendment Act, 1964 substituted the new definition of business with retrospective effect flowing from the language of section 9

anchor.surface_text: It has not been contended before us on behalf of the Revenue that the turnover of the sales by the fair price shop and the canteen could be included in the taxable turnover according to the definition of business as it stood in the original Act. The contention raised is that S. 2 of the Second Amendment Act 1964 substituted the new definition of business with retrospective effect. This result flows, it is said, from the language of S. 9 although in S. 2 of that Act no such language has been used as can give retrospective operation to the amendment made. We are unable to agree that S. 9 by itself would make the definition of business as substituted in s. 2 retrospective.

issues.text: Whether section 9 of the Madras General Sales Tax Second Amendment Act, 1964 validates the levy and collection of tax on sales not in the course of business under the original Act by removing the grounds of invalidity

arguments.claim: Section 2 of Second Amendment Act 1964 substituted new definition of business with retrospective effect via Section 9

anchor.surface_text: It has not been contended before us on behalf of the Revenue that the turnover of the sales by the fair price shop and the canteen could be included in the taxable turnover according to the definition of business as it stood in the original Act. The contention raised is that S. 2 of the Second Amendment Act 1964 substituted the new definition of business with retrospective effect. This result flows, it is said, from the language of S. 9 although in S. 2 of that Act no such language has been used as can give retrospective operation to the amendment made.

arguments.court_reasoning: S.9 does not make substantive definition retrospective without explicit language; validation must cure defect

arguments.claim: Section 9 does not make substituted definition of business retrospective

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree that S. 9 by itself would make the definition of business as substituted in s. 2 retrospective.

arguments.claim: Validation under Section 9 invalid as it does not remove grounds of illegality like lack of business activity; requires retrospective reenactment or curing defect
Legislature cannot render effective a court judgment ineffective by mere declaration
None of the methods for valid legislative validation adopted in Section 9

holdings.text: We are unable to agree that S. 9 by itself would make the definition of business as substituted in s. 2 retrospective.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree that S. 9 by itself would make the definition of business as substituted in s. 2 retrospective. In State of Tamil Nadu Another v. M. Rayappa Gounder etc. s. 7 of the Madras Entertainment Tax Amendment Act 1966 which was similar to S. 9 mentioned above came up for consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.9 lacks language to impart retrospective effect to the substantive amendment in S.2; it operates as a standalone validation provision.

holdings.text: The principle which has been laid down clearly is that validation of tax which has been declared to be illegal may be done only if the grounds of illegality or invalidity are capable of being removed and are in fact removed.

anchor.surface_text: The principle which has been laid down clearly is that validation of tax which has been declared to be illegal may be done only if the grounds of illegality or invalidity are capable of being removed and are in fact removed. Sometimes this is done by providing for jurisdiction where jurisdiction had no been properly invested before.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedents like State of Tamil Nadu v. M. Rayappa Gounder, validation requires curing specific defects such as lack of jurisdiction or substantive compliance through retrospective reenactment or equivalent measures.

holdings.text: None of these methods has been adopted in the present case. Although the definition of business was substituted by the Second Amendment Act of 1964 it was no made retrospective by the usual words that it should be deemed to have been always substituted no was any other language employed to show that the substantive provision, namely, the definition of business was being amended retrospectively. Section 9, therefore, can be of no avail to the Revenue.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No retrospective deeming language used for substituted definition; S.9 fails to remove defect of transactions not being 'business' under original law lacking commercial character; legislature cannot merely override judgments without curing invalidity.

holdings.text: It has not been contended before us on behalf of the Revenue that the turnover of the sales by the fair price shop and the canteen could be included in the taxable turnover according to the definition of business as it stood in the original Act.

anchor.surface_text: It has not been contended before us on behalf of the Revenue that the turnover of the sales by the fair price shop and the canteen could be included in the taxable turnover according to the definition of business as it stood in the original Act. The contention raised is that S. 2 of the Second Amendment Act 1964 substituted the new definition of business with retrospective effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue concedes lack of coverage under original definition requiring commercial activity; court accepts lower courts' findings on no business activity, no profit motive immaterial but intent and articles of association confirm no trade/commerce.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree that S. 9 by itself would make the definition of business as substituted in s. 2 retrospective. In State of Tamil Nadu Another v. M. Rayappa Gounder etc.  1  s. 7 of the Madras Entertainment Tax  Amendment  Act 1966 which was similar to S. 9 mentioned above came up for companysideration. The question was whether the assessments were validly protected by that section. Reliance was place on certain decisions of this Court which laid down that it is open to the legislature within certain limits to amend the provisions of the Act retrospectively and to declare what the law shall be deemed to have been but it was number open to the legislature to say that a judgment of a companyrt properly companystituted and rendered shall be deemed to be ineffective.

outcome.relief_summary: Revenue's contention that the amendment to definition of 'business' has retrospective effect rejected; Section 9 of no avail
